member.name: T:Outpost31.Core.Avatar.AvtrEnvironment
member.remarks:
An Avatar environment consists of two components: the Avatar System and Avatar System Code.
While both contain the word system, they are not the same! It is important to understand the difference between the two.
For more information about Outpost31, please see the file.

member.name: P:Outpost31.Core.Avatar.AvtrEnvironment.AvtrSys
member.summary: The Avatar System that the Tingen Web Service will interface with.
member.remarks:
It is very important that AvtrSys is set correctly, otherwise lots of bad things can and will happen!
Common Avatar Systems are: UAT, LIVE, SBOX, and BUILD. However, the Tingen Web Service is only
able to interface with the UAT and LIVE Avatar Systems.
Modify the AvtrSys setting
Open the Web.Config file located in the root directory of the Tingen Web Service.
Locate the AvtrSys setting within the applicationSettings section.
Change the value of the AvtrSys setting to the desired value.
Save the changes to the Web.Config file.
For example, to set the Avatar System to `LIVE`:
<setting name="AvtrSys" serializeAs="String"> <value>LIVE</value> </setting>
Changes to the AvtrSys setting will be applied the next time the Tingen Web Service is executed.

member.name: P:Outpost31.Core.Avatar.AvtrEnvironment.AvtrSysCode
member.summary: The Avatar System Code used to login to Avatar.
member.remarks:
The Avatar System Code determines (in part) what Avatar functionality a user has access to while they are logged into an Avatar System.
Organizations may have many different Avatar System Codes, but only a few Avatar .
And just to make things confusing, sometimes an Avatar System Code may be similar or the same as an Avatar System.

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Logger.LogAppEvent.Critical(System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Int32)
member.remarks: This is public because TngnWsvc may need to call it.

member.name: M:Outpost31.Core.Logger.LogAppEvent.Primeval(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Primeval logs are used when the advanced logging infrastructure isn't available.

remarks.para:
Primeval logs can be utilized prior to building the logging infrastructure.
Since primeval logs may be written very quickly, there is a 1000ms delay
before committing data.This can potentially cause performance issues.
Syntax: LogEvent.Primeval(avtrSys, "Optional message.");

member.param: The log message, which defaults to "Primeval log." if not specified.

remarks.para:
About Outpost31
Outpost 31 is the back-end/logic for the Tingen Web Service.
